Woman launches pro-choice petition


News		|
	

Published: 15 June 2020		|
	

Last Updated: 15 June 2020		|
	

		Written by Okeri Ngutjinazo	





 





 

A NAMIBIAN woman, Beauty Boois, has called on Namibians to support a petition to legalise abortion in the country.
Under Namibia’s Abortion and Sterilisation Act 1975, abortions are illegal for women and girls, except in extreme cases such as rape, incest, or when the mother or child’s life is endangered.
Namibia inherited this act from South Africa.
Boois launched the petition last week stating the right to access a legal abortion in Namibia should be accompanied by education relating to sexual health and reproductive rights to prevent unwanted pregnancies, baby dumping and encourage safe, legal abortions.
Boois urged the government to ensure that women and young girls in Namibia are aware of their right to sexual and reproductive health, to manage their health, lives and bodies, and to achieve gender equality.
The petition called for counselling and support structures to provide women, who are considering or who have had an abortion, with the necessary guidance and support to make well-informed decisions.
Deputy minister of health and social services Ester Muinjangue on Friday said abortion is a psychosocial issue that needs attention, adding one needs to look at the advantages and disadvantages thereof to make an informed decision.
She said even if it is legalised, discussion of how it would affect women is necessary.
Muinjangue said this is a topic she would address in parliament. Meanwhile, human rights activist Rosa Namises told The Namibian legalising abortion would allow women to make decisions about their own bodies.
“It would be a choice given to women and it would also be a health and safety measure to prevent backyard abortions. I don’t think women will line up every six months to abort, because that is not what it means. It means a woman is given the opportunity to decide about the pregnancy,” she said.
Namises said the laws that regulate women’s bodies need to consider how this is done.
“Women are given contraceptives, such as a chip in their bodies, but nobody properly explains the effects thereof on their bodies,” she said, adding the contraceptive pill and injection have also not been fully explained to women who use such option.
Namises said the country has researched abortion since 1996 when Libertina Amathila, when she was the health minister, introduced a draft abortion and sterilisation bill for public debate.
The bill was later withdrawn and any plans on the topic shelved.
Former minister of health and social services Bernard Haufiku has touched on the issue in parliament, but the debate never saw the light of day. Namises said there is a mentality emanating from churches, which speaks without understanding.
They wish to control women’s bodies in line with their pro-life beliefs, she said.
Abortion needs to be discussed objectively considering all aspects, Namises said.
She asked why certain aspects of abortion are presented to the public, such as unborn babies thrown into plastic bags, but images of abandoned or starving children are excluded.
President Hage Geingob last year acknowledged that the government would have to legalise abortion to prevent deaths due to backstreet abortions.
“We cannot deny it, it is happening. But it’s better to control it so people can [access reproductive health services] legally, to be supervised and advised,” Geingob said.
The petition can be signed at www.change.org.
